subject: pci_handler: Add pci_handler
commitMessage:
pci_handler: Add pci_handler

Taken most of the logic from phoshpor-ipmi-flash:
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-ipmi-flash/blob/master/tools/io.cpp

Tested: Unit Test + Tested this on a real machine

Signed-off-by: Brandon Kim <brandonkim@google.com>
Change-Id: I546d1dff8764e31c9f2fa6c7465ba23a24f6fdea

getting kind of tired of the `std::`. Can we just remove it? for all primitive types?
Yeah that's fair enough - I picked it up from somewhere and just kept it consistent. I'll drop it across the board for readability.
This should also be wrapped with https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/master/src/stdplus/handle/managed.hpp. Probably should be handle in `sys`.
I mentioned it in the other review (for sys) but I think it's better to "managed" it at this level and keep sys at just the interface override level.
It actually doesn't provide us too much now that I think about it since we cover all the branches.. but this is future proofing since we could add more logic and forget to close for instance.

this will fail if `offset + length` overflows.

Might need to check offset and length separately first
- offset < max(uint16)
- length < max(uint16)
- offset + length < max(uint16)

With that being said, this will be an issue in the second case when.

```
length > max(uint16)
```
will underflow and mess with things.

Not sure how we want to handle the cases, but there are a number of failure cases as is.

Yeah, sorry I probably should have marked this as WIP as the unit tests are not ready and I definitely didn't cover all the corner cases. Let me mark it as WIP, fix it up a little bit (and add unit tests) and I'll let you know when it's ready.
same issue here addressed in the comment above.
Same as above - will make this WIP and update once it's ready for review.
What happens if this offset is wrong? Is there a way to check whether the offset is within bounds?
Yes, Willy mentioned it in in the cpp - I'll be doing a boundary check to ensure that it's within bounds.
same comment above regarding the offset.
Yes, Willy mentioned it in in the cpp - I'll be doing a boundary check to ensure that it's within bounds.
Since you are only declaring all the other methods, would it make sense to move the constructor definition to the cpp file?
Do you think printing errno would be helpful as well?
Since this will create an array of size "length", it has the potential to cause a stack overflow right?

As suggested by William in the now abandoned previous CL with sys mock, moved to stdplus::fd so that we can "Management" for free

No more need to manually call open / close.
{} should be enough. also could combine both if statement.
Could there be a scenario where this allocation can fail? Since this is in the constructor, if mmap fails, what would happen?
Throwing in the constructor is a good way to signal failure for allocation - I'll have to remember to catch and handle the exception properly in the main.

Is this check required? Because you has a another check, 

"uint32_t finalLength = (offset + length < regionSize) ? length : regionSize offset;"

So even if the (length > regionSize), finalLength = regionSize - offset.

Same for write function.
Do you think printing error messages here, would be helpful?
You're right. Let me get rid of the length bigger than regionsize checks.

Good point, will add.

It now looks like:

```
[read] Offset [0] was bigger than regionSize [8] OR length [0] was equal to 0
[read] Offset [9] was bigger than regionSize [8] OR length [1] was equal to 0
[write] Offset [0] was bigger than regionSize [8] OR length [0] was equal to 0
[write] Offset [9] was bigger than regionSize [8] OR length [7] was equal to 0
```
What does ElementsAreArray do really? Not sure if I understand its purpose

It's a matcher for matching the content / elements of the array exactly 

https://google.github.io/googletest/gmock_cook_book.html#matching-containers
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1460703/comparison-of-arrays-in-google-test
It looks like Kasun's latest update to his change led to this being updated. Reverting to patchset 16 and addressing Willy's comments.
should have if not get_option('tests').disabled() around this instead.
yeah makes sense, I'll move some of that test check from the test/meson.build to here

Oh, I think stdplus doesn't need it - but it seems it's good to add the subprojects wrap file for it, so I'll fix that https://github.com/openbmc/google-misc/blob/master/subprojects/ncsid/src/meson.build#L33

I think this can be just

```
return std::vector<uint8_t>(mmap.get().data() + offset, finalLength);
```

Maybe not if you needed to memcpy it.

The memcpy allows us to bypass some std::byte to uint8_t conversion (Which just trying to create a uint8_t vector with {} is refusing to do with:

```
../src/pci_handler.cpp:43:72: error: no matching function for call to ‘std::vector<unsigned char>::vector(std::span<std::byte>::pointer, size_t&)’
   43 |     return std::vector<uint8_t>(mmap.get().data() + offset, finalLength);
      |                                                                        ^
In file included from /usr/include/c++/11/vector:67,
```

I can get around this by doing an reinterpret_cast separately, something like:
```
    uint8_t* mmapIt = reinterpret_cast<uint8_t*>(mmap.get().data() + offset);
    return std::vector<uint8_t>(mmapIt, mmapIt + finalLength);
```

however, this is giving me a funky error:

```
clang-tidy-13 --use-color -export-fixes /tmp/tmpi6f5go2_/tmpdpoqu74e.yaml -p=. .../bios-bmc-smm-error-logger/src/pci_handler.cpp
../src/pci_handler.cpp:44:13: error: avoid repeating the return type from the declaration; use a braced initializer list instead [modernize-return-braced-init-list,-warnings-as-errors]
    return std::vector<uint8_t>(mmapIt, mmapIt + finalLength);
            ^
```

I'll keep the memcpy if that's alright with you
huh! I swear I've always done lowerCamelCase for namespaces - oops TIL I'll fix this and Kasun's as well.

fallback is not needed with `provide` in the wrapper.

You can test it out with changing `stdplus` to like `stdplus_2`

and 

```
[provide]
stdplus_2 = stdplus_dep
```
Oh yeah, that's right with the wrapper provide, I'll remove.
Oh yeah this is actually sorta wrong (luckily, I think it defaults to 0) - good catch. It was from copy pasting from above
this is not needed anymore tests folder will only be used that this is true.
